ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Photoluminescence properties and energy transfer of Ca3WO6:Sm3+ co-doped Eu3+

Affiliation.OrgDivision: School of Physics and Optoelectronic Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: A reddish-orange phosphor, Ca3WO6:Sm3+, was synthesized by the convenient solid-state reaction method and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD). Photoluminescence properties and concentration quenching of Ca3WO6:Sm3+ phosphor have been discussed in the excitation and emission spectra. Ca3WO6:Sm3+ phosphor is able to generate a strong excitation peak, which matches the emission wavelength from near-UV LEDs. Energy transfer from Sm3+ to Eu3+ in Ca3WO6 host is observed and investigated in detail. The chromaticity coordinates of Ca3WO6:Sm3+ can be regulated to approach the NTSC standard values of red phosphor by codoping Eu3+ ions. The photoluminescence properties suggest that novel Ca3WO6:Sm3+, Eu3+ phosphor might have a potential application for near-UV LEDs.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The attractiveness of white light-emitting diodes (LEDs), stemming from their energy savings in combination with high brightness, long operation lifetimes, and environmental protection, positions them as the prime general lighting technology for lighting, display, and scintillation applications [1–3]. White LEDs, therefore, are promising candidates to substitute for the conventional solid-state lighting sources in the coming future. Phosphor-converted approach is recognized as the most common and efficient way to generate white-LEDs devices by combining the RGB tricolor (red, green, and blue) phosphors with near-ultraviolet (near-UV) InGaN-based chips due to its high luminous efficiency, high color-rendering index (CRI), and tunable color temperature. High-performance white LEDs have been fabricated by combining blue phosphor BaMgAl10O17:Eu2+, green phosphor ZnS:Cu+, Al3+ and red phosphor Y2O2S:Eu3+ with near-UV LED chip. Unfortunately, the efficiency of the red phosphor Y2O2S:Eu3+ is much lower than that of the green and blue phosphors [4]. In addition, this sulfide-based phosphor comes into being easily decomposed and causes poisonous gas as it contains toxic elements against strong irradiation and its lifetime is inadequate under the excitation of UV light [5, 6]. Recently, Eu2+-doped nitrides have attracted more attention due to their high stability and high luminous efficiency. For example, Ca2Si5N8:Eu2+ [7], Sr2Si5N8:Eu2+ [8], and MAlSiN3:Eu2+ (M = Ca, Sr) [9] red phosphors have been developing and improving. However, almost the nitrides above have to stand critical preparation conditions, such as high temperature, high N2 pressure and air-sensitive starting powders, etc. which restricts widespread use of the nitrides red phosphors. Therefore, it is an urgent task to search for a new red phosphor with high efficiency and excellent chemical stability under conventional synthesis routes.

The Sm3+ ion has been widely used as an activator of reddish orange emission due to its 4G5/2 → 6H J (J=5/2, 7/2, 9/2 and 11/2) transitions, which can be most suitable source for lighting and display [10–13]. As is well known, the sharp 4f–4f transitions and full width at half maximum hardly dependence on the host matrix since the 4f orbital lies inside and is shielded from the outmost filled 5s 2 and 5p 6 orbitals. Such an inset host dependence of Sm3+ leads to the excellent reproduction quality of optical prosperities of red phosphors especially in the process of mass production and in fabrication of powder pc-LEDs with high junction temperature. And the maximum efficiency of near-UV is at around 400 nm, which is in good agreement with the absorption peak (6H5/2 → 4K11/2) of Sm3+. Hence, Sm3+ ions are expected to be ideal activator for red phosphor for near-UV LEDs.

It is known that hexavalent Mo and W are stabilized not in the primitive ABO3 perovskite structure but in the ordered double perovskite structure,
$\mathrm{A}_{2}^{\mathrm{II}}\mathrm{B}^{\mathrm{II}}\mathrm{B}^{\mathrm{VI}}\mathrm{O}_{6}$ , in which AII is an alkaline earth ion, BII, a divalent metal ion such as Mg, Ca, Ni, and Cu and BVI a hexavalent Mo or W ion. The AII ions are in 12-coordination (Ca2+-site in perovskite, CaTiO3). The BII and BVI ions are in 6-coordination (Ti4+-site in perovskite). The BII and BVI ions are ordered in such a way that every BVIO6 octahedron has only BIIO6 octahedra as nearest neighbor [14, 15]. The compounds Ca3WO6 with ordered perovskite structure are particularly suitable as model compounds for fundamental studies of certain physical properties [16–18] due to the simplicity of the crystal structure. However, studies for the compounds Ca3WO6 are only a few.

In the past work, the photoluminescence properties of Ca3WO6:Eu3+ and the codoped effect of alkaline mental ions on Ca3WO6:Eu3+ had been discussed; we found that Ca3WO6:Eu3+ phosphor could be excited availably by radiations of wavelength in blue (∼460 nm) regions and alkaline mental ions not only acted as flux agent to promote the formation of Ca3WO6 crystal, but also played a role in the charge compensation and Na+ ions had the best charge compensation effect for Ca3WO6:Eu3+ phosphor [19]. Therefore, we synthesized Ca3WO6:Sm3+ phosphor using the same method, and took Na+ ions as the charge compensation agent in this work. What is more, we also studied the luminescence properties of Ca3WO6:Sm3+ phosphors, investigated the co-doped effects of Eu3+ ions on the luminescence properties for Ca3WO6:Sm3+ phosphor and found that Ca3WO6:Sm3+, Eu3+ phosphor might be a potential red phosphor for near-UV LEDs.

Section2.Heading: Synthesis
Section2.Para: The powder samples of Ca3−2x WO6:x(Sm3+, Na+)(CWO: x(Sm, Na)) (x=0, 0.005, 0.01, 0.02, 0.03, and 0.05) were prepared by the solid-state reaction technique. Ca2.96−2y WO6:0.02(Sm3+, Na+), y(Eu3+, Na+)(CWO:x(Sm, Na), y(Eu, Na)) (y=0.005, 0.01, 0.03, 0.05, and 0.08) were synthesized using the same method. The starting materials were CaCO3 (A.R.), Na2CO3 (A.R.), WO3 (A.R.), Sm2O3 (4N), Eu2O3 (4N), and ethanol (A.R.). All raw materials with stoichiometric amounts were mixed homogeneously with small amounts of ethanol (to help grinding) in an agate mortar. The homogeneous mixture was put into a corundum crucible and calcined at 1300 ∘C in air for 6 h.

Section2.Heading: Characterization of samples
Section2.Para: The phase purity of the prepared phosphors was measured by an X-ray diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation (wavelength = 0.15406 nm) at 36 kV tube voltage and 20 mA tube current. The excitation and emission spectra of all the samples were measured by a Hitachi F-7000 Fluorescence Spectrophotometer equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as excitation source. All measurements were carried out at room temperature.

Section2.Heading: Phase purity and crystal structure
Section2.Para:
In order to characterize the phase purity and crystallinity of the as-prepared powder samples, the XRD patterns for all samples were examined. Figure 1 shows the XRD pattern of the powder samples undoped-Ca3WO6, Ca2.90WO6: 0.05(Sm3+, Na+) and Ca2.80WO6:0.02(Sm3+, Na+), 0.05(Eu3+, Na+). It can be seen that three samples all match well the standard data of perovskite structure Ca3WO6 (CWO) (Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) card No. 22-0541). This indicates that the single phase CaWO:x(Sm, Na) and CWO:0.02(Sm, Na), y(Eu, Na) can be synthesized at the sintering temperature of 1300 ∘C. Besides, the XRD patterns for all other samples are the same and no extra diffraction peaks are observed in this paper.
Fig. 1
The XRD patterns of undoped-CWO, CWO:0.05(Sm, Na) and CWO:0.02(Sm, Na), 0.05(Eu, Na) samples. The standard data of CWO (JCPDS NO.22-0541)

Typically, the effective ionic radii (r) of cations are mainly determined by the coordination number (CN). The ionic radii for eight coordinated Ca2+, Sm3+, Eu3+, and Na+ ions is 1.12, 1.08, 1.07, and 1.18 Å, respectively [20]. Obviously, the ionic radii for Sm3+, Eu3+, and Na+ ions is slightly different to that of Ca2+, but much larger than that of 0.60 Å in 6-fold coordination. Thus, based on the ionic radius matching, Sm3+ Eu3+and Na+ ions are expected to substitute for Ca2+ ions via two paths: Sm3++Na+=2Ca2+ and Sm3++Eu3++2Na+=4Ca2+.

SEM photographs of CWO:0.05(Sm, Na) sample are shown in Fig. 2. The SEM image (low magnification) displays that the fine grains are not obvious agglomerated with a slight variation in particle size, and the average size of grains is about 20 um. A detailed study at high magnification presents that morphology of the as-prepared grains is most anomalistic but their surface are smooth. It is worth noting that some fragments and irregular broken lines are observed due to the grinding after calcinations in the agate mortar, which might be disadvantageous to the luminescent properties.
Fig. 2
SEM images of CWO:0.05(Sm, Na) sample prepared by the solid-state method

The compound CWO, crystallizing in a monoclinic system with P21/n(14) space group and covered lattice constants a=5.547 Å, b=5.808 Å, c=8.002 Å, β=90.15∘, and the cell volume V=257.80 Å3, exhibits slight deformation from cubic symmetry. In CWO, there is a framework of WO6 octahedra similar to that of the FeF6 groups in (NH3)3FeF6, but the octahedra are slightly rotated or displaced out of the highest symmetry orientation. The true structure, therefore, becomes monoclinic and falls into space group P21/n [14]. The Ca2+ and W6+ ions are ordered in such a way that every WO6 octahedron has only CaO6 octahedra as nearest neighbor. There exist two types of Ca2+ lattices in the CWO host, where one is coordinated to 12 oxygen atoms and the other is 6-coordination. As a consequence, CWO:Sm should exhibit two types of the crystallographic sites. The compound CWO is particularly suitable as a model for fundamental studies of certain physical properties due to the simplicity of the crystal structure.

Section2.Heading: Photoluminescence properties of Ca3WO6:x(Sm3+, Na+) phosphors
Section2.Para:
The photoluminescence properties of pure CWO host were measured. However, there was no emission of
$\mathrm{WO}_{6}^{6-}$ groups, which suggests that the emission was quenched at room temperature. Figure 3 displays that the excitation spectrum of CWO:0.02(Sm, Na) phosphors monitored with the 604-nm emission consists of a broad band with a maximum at 302 nm and some sharp lines at room temperature. The broad excitation band centered at 302 nm is assigned to the contribution of charge transfer (CT) transition from oxygen to samarium and oxygen to tungsten (Sm3+→O2−, W6+→O2−), only one broad band may be due to overlap between the charge transfer of Sm3+→O2− and W6+→O2−. Figure 4 shows the CT band centered at 302 nm can be fitted well with two bands, band A and band B, by Gaussian fitting. The CT band is due to the electronic transition from the 2p orbital of O2− to the 4f orbital of Sm3+ (band B) and the empty d orbital of W6+ (band A) in
$\mathrm{WO}_{6}^{6-}$ groups in light of molecular orbital theory [21]. The appearance of the charge transfer absorption band of Sm3+ in the excitation spectrum indicates that energy transfer from host to Sm3+ occurs.
Fig. 3
Excitation spectrum of CWO:0.02(Sm, Na) phosphors (λ em= 604 nm)
Fig. 4
CTB band centered at 302 nm in excitation spectrum of CWO:0.02(Sm, Na) phosphors (λ em=604 nm)

Besides, the sharp characteristic excitation peaks of Sm3+ correspond to the f → f transitions within its 4f 5 configuration in Fig. 3, which are attributed to the transitions from the ground state (6H5/2) to the different excited states of Sm3+. The higher intense the excitation band is, the more effectively phosphors absorb the excited energy. Among these excitation transition, 6H5/2 → 4K11/2 (407 nm) is the most intense one, which can be excited availably by radiations of wavelength in near-UV (∼400 nm) regions. CWO:Sm phosphors, therefore, is suitable for near-UV light wavelength conversion and can emit bight reddish-orange light for near-UV InGaN chip excitation.

Figure 5 shows the emission spectrum of CWO:x(Sm, Na) phosphors excited by 407 nm light at room temperature. It can be seen that CWO:x(Sm, Na) phosphors exhibit three major emission peaks centered at 567 nm, 604 nm, and 650 nm, corresponding to the 4G5/2 → 6H J/2 (J=5/2, 7/2, and 9/2) transitions of Sm3+, respectively. Among these, the transition at 604 nm (4G5/2 → 6H7/2) has the maximum intensity, which corresponds to the red emission of CWO:x(Sm, Na) phosphors. The strong red emitting transition of 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 at 604 nm (ΔJ=±1) is a partly magnetic dipole (MD) and partly electric dipole (ED) nature emission band. The other transition of 4G5/2 → 6H5/2 at 567 nm is purely MD natured and at 646 nm (4G5/2 →6H9/2) is purely ED natured, which is sensitive to crystal field. Generally, the electric-dipole (ED) transition of 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 with ΔJ=2 is a hypersensitive transition whose intensity increases as the environmental symmetry of luminescence center decreases while the magnetic-dipole (MD) transition of 4G5/2 → 6H5/2 is not sensitive to the site symmetry [22, 23]. For this reason, the intensity ratio of ED/MD transitions has been used as a measure of the symmetry of Sm3+ environment: the higher the ratio, the more asymmetry is the Sm3+ environment. In this present work, the ED/MD ratio of CWO:x(Sm, Na) phosphor approaches 1:1, so neither of them is dominant. This suggests that Sm3+ ions occupied different two lattice sites at least, of which one has the inversion symmetry and the other has not in the CWO host in the random doping process.
Fig. 5
Emission spectra of CWO:x(Sm, Na) (x=0.005, 0.01, 0.02, 0.03, 0.05) phosphors under 407 nm excitation

Generally speaking, the doping concentration makes a significant effect on the phosphor performance. The effect of the Sm3+ doping concentration (x) in the CWO:x(Sm, Na) (x=0.005, 0.01, 0.02, 0.03, 0.05) phosphors on the relative intensity of the transition of 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 is shown as an inset in Fig. 5. As the result shows the luminescent intensity enhances continually as the concentration of Sm3+ increases, and it reaches the highest intensity when the doping concentration of Sm3+ increases to 0.02. However, the luminescent intensity decreases as long as the concentration is over 0.02 due to concentration quenching. Thus, the optimal doping concentration of Sm3+ in the CWO:x(Sm, Na) phosphor is just about 0.02. In addition, as shown in Fig. 4, the Sm3+ ions concentration makes little influence on the position of the emission spectrum, indicating that no abrupt disturbance to the local structure is occurred by the increasing Sm3+ doping level.

As is well known to us, Blasse had pointed out if the activator is introduced solely on Z ion sites, then there is on the average one activator ion per V/x c N, where x c is the critical concentration, N is the number of Z ions in the unit cell, and V is the volume of the unit cell [24]. The critical distance (R c) can be obtained from the critical quenching concentration by the following equation:
$$R_{\mathrm{c}} \approx 2 \times \biggl(\frac{3V}{4\pi x_{\mathrm{c}}N}\biggr)^{\frac{1}{3}} $$ where the value of V and N are 257.80 Å3 and 2 in CWO crystal, respectively. Supposed that the critical concentration is 0.02, therefore, the critical distance between Sm3+ ions is calculated to be 23.08 Å.

As is well known, the resonant energy transfer mechanism consists of two types: exchange and multipolar interaction. In general, the critical distance of exchange interaction is normally around 5 Å [25], the exchange interaction must hardly play a role in the energy transfer between Sm3+ ions. Thus, the energy transfer among Sm3+ ions is considered as multipolar interaction in CWO:Sm. Speaking of Sm3+, the energy gap between the 4G5/2 and 6F9/2 levels is approximately equal to that of between the 6H5/2 and 6F9/2 levels [26]. Hence, cross-relaxing is most likely to occur between two neighboring Sm3+ ions, as shown in Fig. 6. This is the process whereby excitation energy from a Sm3+ ion decaying from the 4G5/2 level promotes a neighboring Sm3+ from the 6F9/2 to the 6H5/2 state. Therefore, the cross relaxation can occur between Sm3+ pairs for the critical distance (23.08 Å) by multipolar interaction in this paper [27]. The concentration quenching can be ascribed to the cross-relaxing in the Sm3+ pairs.
Fig. 6
Energy level diagrams of Sm3+ displaying the quenching mechanism between Sm3+ ions

Section2.Heading: Energy transfer from Sm3+ to Eu3+ in Ca2.96−2y WO6:0.02(Sm3+, Na+), y(Eu3+, Na+) phosphors
Section2.Para:
In order to investigate the energy transfer from Sm3+ to Eu3+, the excitation spectra of CWO:0.05(Eu, Na) and CWO:0.02(Sm, Na), 0.05(Eu, Na), CWO:0.02(Sm, Na) samples were measured by monitoring the emission at 615 nm, 615 nm, 604 nm, and 604 nm, respectively. Through the comparison for these four excitation spectra as shown in Fig. 7, there is the characteristic excitation peak of Sm3+ at 407 nm in the excitation spectrum of Eu3+ (monitored 5D0 → 7F2 at 615 nm). At the same time, there exists the characteristic peak of Eu3+ at 465 nm in the excitation spectrum of Sm3+, which is monitored the emission at 604 nm corresponding to the transition of 4G5/2 → 6H7/2. These indicate that the energy transfer from Sm3+ to Eu3+ occurs in the CWO:0.02(Sm, Na), 0.05(Eu, Na) phosphors while there may be a back-energy transfer from Eu3+ to Sm3+. One way to better understand the energy transfer between the donor (Sm3+) and the acceptor (Eu3+) is to measure the emission spectrum of Sm3+ under excitation of 407 nm. Figure 8 presents the emission spectra of CWO:0.02(Sm, Na), CWO:0.02(Sm, Na), 0.005(Eu, Na), CWO:0.02(Sm, Na), 0.01(Eu, Na), CWO:0.02(Sm, Na), 0.03(Eu, Na), CWO:0.02(Sm, Na), 0.05(Eu, Na) and CWO:0.02(Sm, Na), 0.08(Eu, Na) samples (λ ex=407 nm). In the emission spectrum of CWO:0.02(Sm, Na) co-doped Eu3+, the emission intensity of Sm3+ decreases monotonically at 604 nm and that of Eu3+ increases endlessly at 615 nm
Fig. 7
Excitation spectra of CWO:0.05Eu, CWO:0.02Sm, 0.05Eu, CWO:0.02Sm samples, monitoring the emission at 615 nm, 615 nm, 604 nm, and 604 nm, respectively
Fig. 8
Emission spectra of CWO:0.02Sm, xEu (x=0, 0.005, 0.01, 0.03, 0.05 and 0.08), samples (λ ex=407 nm)

with the increasing concentration of Eu3+. These interesting results are proved to be that Sm3+ can absorb the 407-nm light, which is transferred efficiently to Eu3+ ions. The reason for this is that the energy gap between the 4G5/2 level of Sm3+ and the 5D0 level of Eu3+ is approximately 600 cm−1; the probability of emitting photons for the Sm3+(4G5/2) → Eu3+(5D0) process is much higher than that of capturing photons for the Eu3+(5D0) → Sm3+(4G5/2) process [28, 29]. Hence, the emission spectrum of CWO: Sm3+, Eu3+ phosphors demonstrates that the energy transfer from Sm3+ to Eu3+ is effective.

To investigate the interaction of energy transfer between Sm3+ and Eu3+, the energy transfer expression of multipolar interaction is given by Dexter [30], 1
$$ \frac{\eta_{0}}{\eta} \propto c^{n/3} $$ where η 0 is the luminescence quantum efficiency of Sm3+ without Eu3+ and η is the luminescence quantum efficiency of Sm3+ with Eu3+. c is the sum of the content of Sm3+ and Eu3+; the value of n being 6, 8, and 10 corresponds to dipole-dipole (d–d), dipole-quadrupole (d–q), and quadrupole-quadrupole (q–q) interactions, respectively. Eq. (1) can be modified to the ratio of luminescence intensities [31–33], 2
$$ \frac{I_{0}}{I} \propto c^{n/3} $$ in which I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of Sm3+ in the absence and presence of the Eu3+, respectively. The dependence of I 0/I of Sm3+ on c 6/3 (n=6), c 8/3 (n=8), and c 10/3 (n=10), respectively, is shown in Fig. 9. The best linear fitting result (R 2=0.99832) is obtained when n=8, suggesting that the dominating energy transfer mechanism is d–q interaction. It is well known that d–d interaction occurs only if the emission band of the sensitizer overlaps the allowed absorption band of acceptors, and Ca2.96−2y WO6:0.02(Sm3+, Na+), y(Eu3+, Na+) is not case, apparently. Thus, d–d interaction is excluded as a main energy transfer mechanism, even though the R 2 factor is 0.89273 when n=6. It is much more common that the d–d interaction is responsible for the energy transfer from Sm3+ to Eu3+ [28, 34].
Fig. 9
The dependence of I 0/I of Sm3+ on c 6/3 (n=6), c 8/3 (n=8), and c 10/3 (n=10), respectively

Making further efforts to investigate the process of energy transfer from Sm3+ to Eu3+ in CWO:Sm3+, Eu3+ phosphors, we draw the energy level diagrams of Sm3+ and Eu3+ showing the energy transfer process. As can be seen in Fig. 10, electrons of Sm3+ are promoted from the ground state (6H5/2) to the excited state (4K11/2) under excitation of 407 nm, then relaxing to the metastable excited state (4G5/2) in a nonradiative (NR) transition way; following this step the nonradiative energy transfer from Sm3+ to Eu3+ occurs and the 5D0 state of Eu3+ is increasingly populated. However, the emission peak of 5D0 → 7F2 is much weak and overlapped by the emission (4G5/2 → 6H7/2) of Sm3+. Thus, the emission of 5D0 → 7F1 is only observed apart from the characteristic peaks of Sm3+ in the emission spectrum of CWO:Sm3+, Eu3+ phosphors.
Fig. 10
Energy level diagrams of Sm3+ and Eu3+ displaying the energy transfer process from Sm3+ to Eu3+

Section2.Heading: Fine tuning of chromaticity coordination for CWO:0.02Sm3+, xEu3+ phosphors
Section2.Para:
As is well known, Sm3+ emits reddish-orange emission whose chromaticity coordinates is much farther away from the NTSC standard values (x=0.670, y=0.330) of red phosphors. This evidently imposes restrictions on its application in the field of light display systems. In this paper, the chromaticity coordinates of CWO:Sm can be regulated to approach the NTSC standard values by codoping Eu3+ ions. The CIE (x, y) chromaticity of CWO:0.02Sm, xEu samples are found to shift systematically to the standard red chromaticity (0.670, 0.330) for NTSC with the increasing Eu3+ content, which is assigned to the efficient energy transfer from Sm3+ to Eu3+. The color coordination of CWO:0.02Sm, xEu samples are calculated accurately with the emission spectra data and listed in Table 1, and the corresponding color points are plotted in the CIE diagram (Fig. 11).
Fig. 11
Color points corresponding to CWO:0.02Sm3+ with different co-doping concentration of Eu3+ in CIE 1931 diagram

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, novel CWO:Sm co-doped Eu3+ phosphors were synthesized by the solid-state reaction method at 1300 ∘C for 6 h. The excitation spectrum shows that CWO:Sm can be effectively excited under excitation of 407 nm, which is good agreement with near-UV LEDs chips.

It can be seen that the optical doping concentration of Sm3+ in CWO is about 0.02 from the emission spectrum, and its concentration quenching can be ascribed to the cross-relaxing in the Sm3+ pairs. The emission spectrum of CWO: Sm3+, Eu3+ phosphors demonstrates that the energy transfer from Sm3+ to Eu3+ is effective. Fine tuning of chromaticity coordination for CWO:0.02Sm phosphors can be done by codoping Eu3+. The CWO:Sm, Eu phosphor might have a potential application in the field of light display systems.
